Spin variance of finite angles can anneal more than its discrete counterpart in quantum teleportation. Thus reducing the physical qubit requirement for specific activities. Just by measuring qubits at specific angles can anneal a logical operation and teleport to another qubit. Superposition can also be exploited to influence other qubits then collapsing of wave functions will reveal intricate qubit histories, useful for computation. Annealing is simply applying inductive fields at specific angles and measuring temperature changes to deduce information.

The Barbarians card is unlocked from the Barbarian Bowl (Arena 3). It spawns five single-target, melee Barbarians with moderate hitpoints and damage. They wield short swords and have blonde hair and moustaches. They are the same as those spawned by the Barbarian Hut, Battle Ram, and the Barbarian Barrel. A Barbarians card costs 5 Elixir to deploy. Strategy The Barbarians are a great option to use against enemy troops such as tanks and medium size pushes as the Barbarians have a moderate amount of hitpoints and damage, and are perfect for attacks with other tanks. Although they are very effective against single target troops like the Prince, Barbarians are susceptible to spells and troops which do area damage due to their slow move-speed. Their slow attack speed also leaves them vulnerable to swarms such as the Skeleton Army.

Despite being a swarm unit, Barbarians are fairly effective against an Electro Giant due to their high DPS and their moderately higher hitpoints compared to other swarm units, allowing them to survive the Electro Giant's reflected damage and defeat him for a +3 Elixir trade, but they will likely die in the process or have an insignificant amount of remaining health. Note that since the Barbarians will have little health remaining, any sort of damage dealt to them besides the Electro Giant's reflected damage will often nullify their defense, so the player should account for supporting troops or accompanying the Electro Giant as well. Due to the amount of counters to a Barbarian and most resulting in a positive Elixir trade for the opponent, it is ineffective to deploy a group of Barbarians without support in one lane, as they can be easily countered due to their slow speed and can leave the player vulnerable to a push in the other lane. However, if the opponent is extremely low on Elixir, or their best counters are out of rotation, they can be very effective at forcing the opponent to spend Elixir poorly, as they can quickly chop down cheap troops and will completelv destrov a Crown Tower by

themselves. They are excellent for taking out low numbers of enemy troops such as the Prince or Musketeer on the player's side. The 5 Barbarians will quickly eliminate the unit if they are dropped directly on top of it, surrounding it. The Barbarians can be effectively countered by most ranged splash troops such as the Bomber and Wizard from a distance. However, you must be careful as the opponent can use a Tornado or Freeze to immobilize or destroy the splash attacker, allowing the Barbarians to devastate the Crown Tower. A powerful counter is the Fireball; the damage and radius of the spell is more than enough to one-shot the Barbarians. However, keep in mind that if the Fireball is underleveled, or if the Barbarians are overleveled, it will not one-shot them. Additionally, the Barbarians can also act as a bait for these counters, allowing you to use other cards that would be weak to Fireball, such as Zappies. Poison can also be an effective counter to use. Its damage over time will eliminate the Barbarians and any supporting troops. However, as with Fireball, it will not defeat Barbarians with a level higher than the Poison. A Rocket can also defeat them, however it is a negative Elixir trade. It is best to be used if the Barbarians are assisted with another card Rage used with Barbarians can do severe damage to a Crown Tower, as it is hard to stop because Rage increases movement and attack speed. The Barbarians together have high damage and can make short work of a tower before the opponent stops them. They are very effective at defeating enemy tanks due to their numbers (5 of them), high combined damage, and ability to tank most spells. Support troops will have trouble defeating them due to their combined hitpoints. If the combo happens to be any ground-based splash damage card + ground- based melee tank, wait for the troops to cross the river. As soon as they cross, immediately drop the Barbarians upon the splash card. They will surround and destroy it quickly before moving on to eliminate the now unsupported tank. This can result in a large positive elixir trade. However, if there is more than one splash unit, the Barbarians are likely to be taken out immediately. Note that this may be ineffective against a P.E.K.K.A. as she can one-shot Barbarians up to 2 levels higher. They are very effective against Hog Riders and Ram Riders. Not only do they deal a lot of damage to these troops, but their high mass and slight spread forces the Hog Rider and Ram Rider to go around them, extending their distance from the Princess Tower. Because of this, the Barbarians can easily defeat these units with no damage to the Princess Tower. The Barbarians, if placed early enough, can surround the Princess Tower, making it less vulnerable to attacks from a Goblin Barrel. They can handle it quite well with only minimal damage done. However, this is a 5 Elixir investment so consider using it if you lack better counters. Splitting the Barbarians in the back can discourage the opponent from attacking either Princess Tower, due to the Barbarians' defensive presence, and spells will not have as much value. However, they are slow moving and as such, the opponent might deal some unnecessary damage before the Barbarians arrive on their target. Due to beina 5 of them, thev can act as a Lightning rod for more fragile units like a Magic Archer or a Flying Machine. 2 of them will also survive for extra protection for the guarded fragile units. Scientists today are acutely aware of the phenomenal capacity of quantum information processing. For this reason they try in a great hurry to construct so-called “quantum computers”.

Since quantum information processing is a natural capability of the Universe since its very beginning, it is highly likely that the Universe itself is already using it.

Unfortunately, the fundamental quantum information processing of the Universe itself is banned from consideration here on Earth.

In the beginning of the 21st century science firmly believes that the basis of all quantum processes in the Universe is chaos.

Belief in chaos and randomness of quantum processes was initiated by some famous people in the past century, who failed to imagine an explanation for “apparently random” behavior of elementary particles such as electrons.

As a result of this glaring lack of imagination, the so-called “uncertainty principle” has been adopted as a foundation of all sciences on Earth.

The uncertainty principle, in its essence, brutally averages-out all traces of the quantum information processing of the Universe and estimates “probabilities” of some primitive set of locally averaged quantum events.

The most famous critic of the uncertainty principle as a way to describe the fundamental activity of the Universe was Albert Einstein, who insisted that “God does not play dice”. Unfortunately, like all his contemporaries, he failed to imagine and propose a plausible explanation for apparently random behavior of elementary particles such as electrons. In the absence of intelligent critics, the uncertainty principle gained the status of a sanctified dogma that is not even allowed to be questioned.

However, quantum-domain information processing in the Universe continues and will continue everywhere, no matter how many authorities and laureates choose to deny it...

Minute 4.26. This is a standard mistake that even many people in the field still make about entanglement. If Alice and Bob are given 2 bits with the promise of being in 00 or 11, then if Bob looks at its bit he knows immediately the bit of Alice. This is all classical, no quantum needed…entanglement is much more subtle than this,  and it necessitates the ability to select the measurement basis to manifest its weird features. As someone that does research in quantum computing, some of this is a bit misinformed.

No, you absolutely cannot do "all the calculations at the same time".

There is no inherent exponential information advantage between a classical computer and a quantum computer. Quantum superposition can really be seen as a slightly quirkier form of a *probability distribution*, which is something you can perfectly well also achieve in a classical setting. 8 probabilistic bits contain exactly the same amount of information as 8 quantum bits.

There are some very specific ways in which the quirks of how superposition works can result in some suprising exponential speedup for *Very specific problems*. But that such an advantage exists is extremely non-trivial, quite rare, and certainly does not stem just from there being "more information" or anything of the sort. For most settings, the best (and provably so) advantage we can gain with a quantum computer is polynomial, so "square root" or something of the sort, if any at all. For many of the most common tasks, quantum computers offer no advantage whatsoever.

This video did not explain quantum computers properly or clearly.  Quantum computers use probability or the 5th dimension to rule out improbable super positioning.  By having super positioning or the six dimension they are able to solve probability equations in the 5th dimension.  By ruling out improbability the computer only needs to calculate a smaller number of equations to arrive at the solution to the equation.   As more checks are added the probability keeps narrowing the number of possible outcomes until its at 100%.  Though, the name quantum computers is misleading.  Regular computers are also quantum in that they speed up time we can solve equations at the 4th dimension.  the fact that quantum computers are only able to deduce equations at the 5th dimension rather than the 6th dimension means its not able to out perform the human brain which accesses at least the 7th dimension or connection parallel time lines..

Basically super position is the atom equivalent of "If a tree falls in the woods does it make a sound".
Yes it does. And Atoms have either horizontal or vertical polarization. Super position is just an extremely complicated way to say "we don't know unless we see it".

Eg if your parents bought a new car and didn't tell you the color. You wouldn't know what color it was till you saw it. But you not seeing the color doesn't change the color the car was manufactured with. Humans like to think the world revolves around them. Super position is the equivalent concept of "We either guess right or we call it a prediction".

Takeaway is that quantum computers are much stronger than normal computers. The longer it takes for a normal computer to do a calculation, simulation, or any resource intensive activity the better the quantum option becomes. For example, if it takes a computer 3 seconds to load a new level, a quantum computer can do it in <3. If it takes a computer 5 years to run multiple simulations, a quantum computer can do it in 10 hours or so.

It is my understanding that the biggest obstacle of quantum computers is maintaining the precision of the qubits-- which is a fundamental engineering problem -- and the more qubits you have, the more difficult it is to maintain the needed precision. Unfortunately, after 50 years of quantum computer research, there has been little progress in this particular facet of quantum mechanics.

This does not mean we shouldn't work on these things, by any means: after all, a solution might unexpectedly present itself. It may mean that quantum computers will be like fusion, namely, something that will be available 20 years in the future, like it has been for the last 50 years.

Coincidetally, I learned recently that fusion is actually a quantum process -- the same quantum tunnelling that makes it so difficult to make transistors especially small also makes it possible for the nucleus of one hydrogen atom to combine with another!

I think part of the problem of understanding quantum mechanics is the lack of language skills of those describing what is going on. Let's take a closer look.
Qubits apparently are fickle teenage girls, existing in four states at once, exhilarated, depressed, heartbroken, and swooning, with four intensities of each. You go to ask if she could empty the dishwasher, for example. You won't know which until you abruptly open the door to her room, where she is currently in all four moods at once (she's watching CNN and Fox News) and every level that mood can be and in an instant, she decides to pick just one then collapses on the floor, clearly extremely depressed. You were hoping for slightly exhilarated...
She may also be entangled in a murder/suicide pact with another qubit who, when found and examined, will be in the exact opposite mood.
What's worse is that when you open the door to her room, it may not even be the same person that went to sleep there last night. Close the door and knock, fingers crossed!

When quantum computing takes off we're actually going to be in an alright position to take advantage of it in the industry. I say that because of the new wave of cloud computing, and Software as a Service in general. Having a personal quantum computer is probably not going to be viable for a very long time, but a large data center you use a fraction of the resources from? Absolutely useful. It's a double edged sword since this wave of SaaS and stuff like it is another blow to the entire concept of ownership of your own property, and I've got some massive issues with that. However, if we finally update the regulations on that or society shifts to make such anti-customer practices untenable, we might be able to use it without too much harm. The benefits are nothing to sneeze at after all. It's not just good for medicine, and database searches aren't just boring fact retrieval jobs. Quantum computing would do some fairly terrifying things to video game servers. I wonder if the superposition thing would allow you to do something like, calculate all possible actions an entity could make, and when data comes from the player indicating the one they made or a set of reasonable possibilities, the server already has the math done.

I admit I'm not 100% sure how to talk about this, normal code can get hard as is. I just hope it makes it easier to have large scale, complex, and detailed game worlds so we can finally have the big space game that people keep trying and failing to successfully make.

This is mind bending alright. Using quantum computation to simulate our environment. Maybe it will be a while, but it will be simulated to increasing degrees of complexity, eventually becoming indistinguishable from the real thing. This is that weird mystical space where the objective and subjective universes converge, and you see the fractal of existence create self repeating patterns inside the simulation. Then the thought occurs, "Just what is consciousness?" Our brains can perform the computations that give rise to consciousness, but all matter is doing computations, just not in a meaningful way so we say it lacks consciousness and is not living. But maybe it is doing meaningful computations, it's just not anything that we limited humans are capable of understanding so we call it non living. So could it be that non living is just a human misconception, and the whole universe is one big brain doing meaningful computation across eternity? Now we're talking about God. The sum of all computations through time and space, and we are each part of this process.
As outlandish as this sounds to people, this is actually an idea explored in ancient myths. Brahma is a Hindu god that dreams the universe. What does that sound like to you? Brahma can be likened to the computer, the simulation is the dream. There is an Isaac Asimov story called The Last Question that contains a similar idea as well. Kurzgesagt put out another Asimov story in a video called The Egg that contains an idea related to this. When I got high one day as a teenager, this idea hit me and I thought I was going nuts. "Sane people don't think like this," I thought. Then I kept hearing this idea repeated over and over again as I got older, and now I'm convinced this is just people connecting the dots and coming to a logical conclusion.

Does anyone else feel like the logic gate diagrams are wrong? Maybe I need a more informed person's explaining, but even the NAND and AND gates seem like someone didn't know what they were doing, and idk what to say for the XOR gate...
Since it's clear the AND gate is designed to change when he uses it as an example (which even then doesn't seem to me like a good representation after the fact), I will use NAND to express my confusion.

Here's how I understand them to work:
The transistors don't technically let information go through, they let an electrical current pass through, and represent the bits themselves, where 1 = open/on/passed-through and 0 = closed/off/blocked. The status of the 1 or 0 is then used in combination with millions of other transistors, to represent data that the computer is processing.

However, in the NAND diagram, all it shows is that bit 'A' is off, so "current go to yes arrow"... this however shows nothing about the the NAND function...
I drew my own diagram on a whiteboard:



I feel like this is a much better example, but if there's some reason for the presumed lack of detail on the video, or if anyone has any objections to my diagram, I'd be interested to know.

Edit: Youtube seems to not allow pictures in comments. Oh well... I give up I'll ask somewhere else.

Slow down there Nellie! This reminds me, almost verbatim, of an article I read on the subject several years back, but I was confused then as I am now, and I have a degree in Electrical Engineering with an emphasis in IC design and fabrication, so I know a little about how computers work...
After watching this video, I have come to realize that there seems to be a lot of information that is missing here that would help to explain things better. For one, what is this "quantum gate" that you portray as a simple ring in the video? I analogize that this would have to be similar to an ALU in a processor, which generally requires a ripple of logic events to occur before the final bits could be set to something new. This takes time. So does the transport of the electron to the "quantum gate". As far as I can tell, all this time to access these bits are going to add up to a time that is for now, longer than the time it takes for normal processors to complete the same calculation.
We also need to consider the entire apparatus that allows a quantum bit to be stored in a stable environment to be counted as part of the overall size of the equivalent flop-transistor module it is replacing. As far as I understand, there is no conception of anything even close to that size in anyone's minds. Unless there is, but then I think it would be important to talk about that.

Not to be picky on an old video, but "approaching the size of an atom" on the transistor/in the introduction/30sec in, in fact the transistors in computers used by most individuals, companies and say for scientific purposes, are not on the "atom scale" size-wise. 1 hydrogen atom is about 53 picometer in diameter, that would put it to roughly 18,867 hydrogen atoms to 1nM. The more recent transistor-node sometimes mentioned is 10 nanometer node, which has a pitch value of about 35nM and a width of about 7.5nM, (basically the size without height included), to point out with the transistor thing, we still have decades of inventing to do before scaling starts to become a problem.

Anyone watching this better go and read scholarly articles and other materials about dwave computing. According to Dwavesys (the company) these computers absolutely do not work off 1's and 0's.

"1.2 - A new kind of computing
Quantum computing is radically different from the conventional approach of transforming bits strings from one set of 0's and 1's to another. With quantum computing, everything changes. The physics that we use to understand bits of information and the devices that manipulate them are totally different. The way in which we build such devices is different, requiring new materials, new design rules and new processor architectures. Finally, the way we program these systems is entirely different. This document will explore the first of these issues, how replacing the conventional bit (0 or 1) with a new type of information - the qubit - can change the way we think about computing." dwavesys(dot)com

RSA-160 uses 160 for the prime number. Breaking that encryption is not an hard task for your computer even today, but quantum computers can't do it since they usually have less than 8 bits of total memory.

For the current time, they are massive and they require a lot more tahn a normal consumer computer requires to run, just like the computers back in 60s and 70s. They will evolve, we are sure about that and we migh aswell use the information we have about the quantum computers and how they work to make our transistors even smaller than 3nm in the future. They will probably take many years since we are not really in 7nm era (even tho companies tell us that we are using 7nm chips in our computers, they are not really 7nm chips. This video was 5 years ago. A few weeks ago, Google's quantum computer achieved a relatively basic level of quantum supremacy- they were able to make a computation that would take a normal supercomputer 2.5 days to complete, in 3 minutes and 20 seconds. This isn't anywhere near the potential of an actual functioning quantum computer, but it shows enormous progress. The raw processing power of their machine is 1081.08 times greater than that of a conventional supercomputer, an unimaginable leap in computational capability, and by my reckoning, theirs isn't even the best quantum computer currently in development. IBM and their team show greater potential in my opinion, but regardless of who comes out on top, the race between those two, and many more possible contenders, is going to be even more fascinating to watch as the future unfolds. We're just taking our first baby steps now. In another 5 scant years, we'll likely long have surpassed what is considered a "true quantum supremacy" proof- taking 3 minutes and 20 seconds to complete an equation that would take a classical, or, conventional supercomputer 10,000 years. I can only imagine what comes next.

Kurzgesagt videos are very intelligent and beautiful, but they are sometimes so fast that I can understand only a fraction of each video. It seems to me that the speed of these videos is suitable for someone who already knows the subject of the video, but for someone who is trying to understand and learn, it is mission impossible. Human brain just doesn't work that fast.

Many smart YouTube videos are actually creating this culture of not understanding that you don't understand, you just click Like, feel smart and move on. Maybe it's just me, maybe I am mentally slow, as some commentators in the past have suggested. But I think I'm just a bit intellectually old-fashioned in the sense that I seek to understand the stuff that I see and hear.

I get it that life these days is so fast, so hectic, that human brains can't handle it so they cope by being superficial, as they can't afford to absorb the details. But understanding stuff requires precisely that. Kurzgesagt videos are amazing and I am very sad because of this Superman tempo of narration, which doesn't allow me to absorb the details and to understand the subject, no matter how beautifully you guys write and illustrate it.

BTW, my favorite narrators are David Attenborough and Richard Dawkins. Of course, they are much more than narrators, but their audiobooks for example are very rich in detail, yet they narrate it so that they allow my brain to understand them without strain. I don't mean any disrespect, especially since you are excellent at making videos, but I just wanted to give my feedback.

hold on kurzgesagt. You've got most of your stuff right, but your conclusion is a little bit off. Quantum computing is hard, like unbelievably hard. There will literally never be a consumer laptop or desktop that can take "advantage" of quantum computing because Qbits have to be incredibly well isolated to be in superposition. Also, even if it were possible, a consumer computer would actually be slower if it were running a quantum system.  So the limit of technology of quantum computers is that it will be a specialized tool. Great for running simulations and solving NP hard problems, but pretty much nothing for a consumer.

There were a couple misleading parts in this video. The description of how quantum computers work didn't capture why they are special; everything you said (e.g. superposition, computing everything in parallel) is also true of a "normal" computer equipped with random numbers. The thing that makes quantum computers special is interference; some of the parallel paths can cancel each other out. Without that, superposition would be useless.

Also, it's not really true that the motivation for quantum computers is physical limits of transistors. We started studying quantum computing long before those limits were a problem, and there's not much overlap between people working on quantum computing and people working on smaller transistors. They're just separate issues - both interesting and important.

Since this video has been released, transistors have decreased in size furthermore. An iPhone XS or later has a transistor size of 7 nm, which was pretty revolutionary since it was one of the only devices to be mass-produced with such an architecture. In the past year, however, 7 nm transistors are becoming more prevalent in PCs. In 2019, 5 nm technology has become commercialized, though not on a massive scale. Even now, Samsung has announced they plan to commercialize 3 nm technology.


The important thing to note here is that we design these transistors often decades before they become commercial. For example, 10 nm technology was first designed in the 1980s before being created in 2002 and commercialized in 2016. Currently, the smallest transistor created is at 2.3 nm, which may signal that we are at an end for transistors, considering how the disparity between the size of created transistors and the size of commercialized transistors has diminished greatly.


Currently, some major nanotech research firms have considered 14-angstrom transistors (14Å, one angstrom is 10^-10 meters, 1 ten-billionth), which is about half the width of a DNA helix, by around 2025. However, whether or not we will be able to actually realize this is up for debate for the reasons mentioned in this video.

This explanation doesn't make much sense to me.
You're saying that these qubits havea a superpoisition, where it contains more information than 1 or 0. Interpreting that information sounds like looking at a rainbow and asking "which ONE color is it?". In that case you either get a confusing answer from a qubit, or most of the information is useless in it.
You also said that at the point of measurement the qubit falls out of superposition. That implies to me that it would constantly have to fall in and out of superposition whenever it's changed inside a computer. Because if you want to know what information a qubit is carrying, you have to measure it, and to change it in a meaningful way, you have to know what information it has. Unless you knew the exact states and outcomes from the beginning, but that makes the whole process useless and doable with conventional computers.


This would mean that the superposition property, which is the main (only?) advantage of quantum computing is ultimately useless.

I always wondered if quantum entaglement could be used to send data near instantly across any distance.

For example, a super computer with entangled output qubits linked to input qubits in another computer the entire world away. If the output is measured to be 1 (or forced to be 1) then the input the world away would be 0, and so information can be shared across the world by encoding info in the output computer in opposite to the computers actual computational result.

The application here, besides data transfer without lag, is that super computers could be built on distant planets or orbiting stars, magnificent in scale and power, and the info could be read by a much smaller computer on our planet.

But then, I'm no quantum scientist and my knowledge of the subject is fairly limited, I just wondered if it was a possibility. Is there a limit in physical distance of two quantum entagled qubits, and can we force a qubit to always give us the desired unit we would like?

256 bit encryption will never be broken no matter how fast the CPU is and no matter the technology....
A single Facebook password would take more time to decrypt then the entire existing time of the universe, more then 11.5. Quadrovegillion combinations, say 1 try takes about 2 seconds which when you start working with those massive numbers with over 60 zeros takes much longer, but for simplicity sake, lets say it's 2 secs per try. It would take over a vigillion years to do so. Do you know how much time that is? In that much time our universe will have no stars, most likely will experience another big bang and the entirety of the universe will be gas, then that gas thanks to gravity will make stars, which will explode and make planted and so on and so forth, that will happen over 2300 times before the so called super computer is done decrypting the password.

For crying out loud stop making these videos where you represent the new cutting edge technology when you have no idea where it will be used. The fact is that quantum computing can be sort of virtualized through running complex algorithms and optimizing the searches which ultimately increases the hardware demand but also in some cases makes a lot of sense.
For example, I made a bot for Microsoft rewards to steal from bills massive fortune of over 80 billion dollars.
Now instead of making the bot run in series meaning run account after account, I made it get unsearched accounts, regroup them into N amount of chunks and make a new session for each to run on and run N bots in parallel. This increases your productivity N amount of times if you meet the optimal requirements where the each bot will run at its fastest.
If you did the same thing, ran 10 bots at q time and by doing that you increase the boot time by 8 secs, your bot is better off running 7 ACC's at a time (which is a number that was a result of complex math I did.
I've also done similar things in database searches. When you search for a certain name in a database, and you only have a first name, you can make 4 different chunks each having 1/4 of the total amount of names and then run search with a basic for loop, you make it 4 times faster but also much harder on your CPU. So instead of making a super computer, get a CPU that has a lot of cores and threads, make a language that can optimally make use of each core and then use that language as a foundation for other languages which will be used on high end machines.
Would make the FBI database searches much faster, but since they are too stupid to think of it themselves I have to be the one to present this solution to inovation clubs to be told "that would take a lot of time and effort, also requires a lot of change and would lead to a lot of jobs being lost so not a good business idea"

Little lesson in the building blocks of our universe! We know what molecules are, things like H2O. The H2O molecule contains two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom. Atoms consist of protons, neutrons and electrons. Electrons cannot be further divided! That means they are a quantum particle. Neutrons and electrons consist of quarks, of which there are only 6: up, down, top, bottom, charm and strange. These quarks are held together by something called gluons, which create a very strong bond between the quarks.
In particle physics, we have three groups: the quarks (mentioned above), the leptons and the bosons. The quark sare the building blocks for protons and neutrons and are bound together by gluons, a boson. The electron belongs to the leptons, just like tau and muon. These three all have a charge of negative 1, but they also have a neutral counterpart called the electron, tau and muon neutrinos, which have a charge of 0. These 6 particles are the leptons and do not mess with things like gluons. Electrons can exchange energy in the form of photons, the light 'particle'. Then there are the W and Z bosons, which are responsible for the process of radioactivity and mess with the neutrinos. They are also able to change the nature of a quark, so transforming an up quark in a strange quark for example. Lastly we have the famous Higgs boson, the particle that gives mass to other particles.
Now to summarize, we have 17 particles, 6 quarks, 6 leptons and 5 bosons. The quarks are the 'matter' particles, the leptons are the other ingredient for the formation of atoms and are essential for the charge of a molecule and the bosons are the particles that carry the four fundamental forces. The photon governs electromagnetic force, the gluon governs the strong nuclear force, the W and Z bosons govern the weak nuclear force and the higgs boson governs mass (the Higgs field is responsible for gravity itself).

🔸Superposition - allows you to hold all possible combinations of bits in a single combination. That basically allows you to hold more data without taking too much space. It's also good for quickly extracting something.

🔸Entanglement - you don't need to check each and every bit to know the full combination. For example, in the binary number 1011, a normal computer will have to check each digit one by one to confirm that the number is 1011. But a quantum computer just needs to check the first digit (i.e. 1) and it will instantly know the full number.

🔸Qubit manipulation - To do anything, a computer needs to do calculations. Different types of calculations are done by different logic gates, so a computer needs different kinds of logic gates. A quantum gate, however, serves the purpose of all logic gates at once. So basically one quantum gate does all sorts of calculations.

Também conhecido como aruanã, Presente tanto nas Bacias do Amazonas como também no Araguaia-Tocantins. Conhecidos por serem grandes saltadores, podendo alcançar altura superior a um metro em cada pulo. O aruanã procura realizar a reprodução durante épocas de enchentes. O macho protege os ovos com a boca. Considerada espécie ornamental – com valores altos no âmbito comercial.

Barbado

Pode ser chamado também de piranambu, encontrado, além do Amazonas, na Bacia do Prata, região que inclui o território pantaneiro. Tem importância à pesca de subsistência por nadar nas beiras dos rios que cercas vilas de pescadores ou pequenas cidades no aspecto populacional. A dieta da espécie é composta por diversos itens alimentares. Costuma a atacar inclusive peixes que são pescados com redes, disputando o alimento com os pescadores.

Bicuda

Possui formado comprido no corpo e bico. Interessante notar que não apreciam nadar em cardumes com muitas espécies. Também não fazem migrações para desovar na época da criação. Não traz gosto agradável e por este motivo não é visado comercialmente, o que favorece contra riscos de extinções. Por outro lado, os esportistas apreciam pescar bicudas por causa do alto nível de dificuldade. O peixe, além de forte, é capaz de dar saltos altos para não se entregar aos pescadores. Prefere habitar as superfícies por causa das características pelágicas.

Peixe-boi
popularmente como peixe-boi,é um mamífero da família dos triquecídeos que é encontrado em rios e lagos da Bacia Amazônica e da Bacia do Rio Orinoco[2]. Tais animais chegam a medir até 2,8 metros de comprimento, possuindo um corpo cinzento e uma grande mancha esbranquiçada no peito.

Boto-cor-de-rosa
É o maior golfinho de água doce, e um dos cetáceos com dimorfismo sexual mais evidente, com os machos medindo e pesando 16% e 55% mais do que as fêmeas. Os adultos apresentam uma coloração rosada, mais proeminente nos machos. Como outros odontocetos, possui um órgão chamado melão utilizado para ecolocalização.

Ósseos
Cachorra

O nome comum na região amazonense é peixe-cachorro. Encontrado também em ampla variedade no Araguaia. Natural de mata inundada, lagos, canais e rios. São peixes grandes que preferem se alimentar de espécies com no máximo cinquenta por cento.

Curimatã
Considerado como um dos peixes mais apreciados em solos amazonenses. Tem coloração em prata e porte médio. Traz dentes pequenos e afiados, além de variedade nas escamas. Prefere se alimentar de microrganismos e materiais orgânicos encontrados na lama presente no fundo dos rios.

Curimbatá
Considerado como um dos peixes mais belos de todas as bacias amazônicas. Pode ser encontrado no Amazonas, Pantanal, Araguaia, São Francisco e alguns açudes nordestinos. Considerado como peixe detritívoro, ou seja, que se alimenta de restos orgânicos encontrados na lama do fundo dos lagos ou nas margens

Cartilaginosos

Pristidae é a única família da ordem Pristiformes e compreende espécies vulgarmente conhecidas como peixes-serra. A sua característica principal é a maxila muito alongada, com dentes iguais colocados regularmente nos bordos exteriores.

Depois de muitos anos de anonimato e de já enfeitar milhares de aquários de colecionadores asiáticos, a Potamotrygon tigrina, uma espécie de arraia amazônica, foi finalmente descrita pela ciência.

For those who don't understand:

Quantum physics is completely different from normal physics. And with these new laws of physics, normal computers don't make sense. So quantum computers are computers that use the laws of quantum physics. And they mainly do this via superposition, or a bit in an indefinite position. Normal bits are a 1 or a zero, but a q-bit can be either one until it is defined. This is a complete game changer, as it can create entirely new combinations of bits. This combination goes at an exponential rate, and goes from 2 to the power of every bit.

Qbits also use entanglement. This is a way a qbit can react to a change in each other instantly without you even having to define the qbit.

And instead of using logic gates (series of transistors) quantum computers use quantum gates, which takes an input of superposition and creates another one, and then uses quantum gates to define the qbits.

All of this makes quantum computers operate much much faster than normal computers, going so fast they might even be able to break encryption.

NP-Complete problems such as TSP, 3-CNF, Hamilton, etc. - will be solved in square root of the amount of running time it would take on a normal non-quantum computer. But it will be still on an exponential level - the amount of running time in these kind of search/decision problems.
But NP-Intermediate problems such as RSA will be solved in polynomial time even if they won’t be proven as problems in P.

The essence of "Quantum computing" is using probabilistic algorithms (quite similar to Monte Carlo) for tasks solving. There is class of tasks, that could be solved with these type of algorithms efficiently (but you can't for example calculate a + b). And on special devices that use quantum properties of the (small size) systems it is possible to simulate these algorithms directly (due to probabilistic nature of quantum physics (and so (small size) systems properties) and so efficiently (instead of brute force (usual) calculation). These devices are called "Quantum computers".
I believe that this explanation is much more clear and informative.

More about future computer:

Worrying about the future, forecasting the future has become one of the focal points of humanity, especially in the last century, with an even greater increase. This curiosity gets even more meaningful when artisans are converted by literary scientists or screenwriters. Science fiction lovers These films, which have a futuristic story like The Return to the Future, The Minority Report, Star Trek or Ben Robot, are always delighted to watch the future with breathtaking graphics of the future depicted. What kind of future could we have thought if we looked at the future not only from science-fiction but from science? Scientific principles clearly explain what we can build in the future or what we can not build. For example, today, when engineers consider the principles of mechanistic physics when designing rockets sent to space, keeping these principles in mind holds us as close as we can imagine how these rockets could be built in the future. In this article we will also talk about the future of one of the most important products of the technology revolution, considering the knowledge: the future of the computer.

Today, computers in at least one house are undoubtedly one of the integral parts of the technology revolution. The first vacuum computers that cover a large room have emerged since the 1950s, a little over a half a century, computers have shrunk to the size of a handful today and become devices that everyone can easily have. Undoubtedly, the underlying reason for the developments that take place at this incredible speed is, of course, the exponential growth in computer power. To understand this growth, we can give an example that the singing teddy bears are once more powerful than the computer powers the world's greatest armies possess.

Can these developments in advanced computer technology continue this way forever?

To understand this we need to talk about Moore's Law. This law takes the name of Gordon Moore from the founders of the name of Intel. Moore's law briefly says that the power of the computer will double in 18 months. When we think of the example we mentioned above, it is not against our intuitions. As we have seen from our historical perspective, the law is getting tough. On the other hand, even today's most advanced computers are far below the processing capacity of a human brain, but if this law continues to be valid, half a century later computers can go beyond the processing capacity of the human brain. This leads to another debate, arguing that artificial intelligence will destroy humanity, but we will not talk about it here. What we are trying to emphasize is how important this law is.

Now that I'm back in charge, can the Moore's Law last forever? Unfortunately, our response is no. Even Gordon Moore himself claimed in 2007 that this law had a life span of about 20 years. The whole magic may seem to be corrupted, but the answer is based on a cause of physics that is not related to technology, which is why it is no. Now we will explain this in the light of the scientific principles we emphasize at the beginning of the article.

We talked about Moore's law, but we did not talk about the reason behind the exponential growth of computer power. The main reason for this is the transistors. As these electronic components are miniaturized, the computer power increases inversely. So the point to be reached when explaining the no answer is to find out how far we can shrink the transistors.

The main problem here is that the Heisinberg Uncertainty principle, which is one of the basic principles of quantum physics when transistors are reduced to the level of atoms, comes into play. Practically, the uncertainty principle allows the transistors to be reduced to a certain size, not later. This principle simply states that the position and speed of an electron can not be determined at the same moment. The effect of this is that when the electronic components on the computer chip become smaller, the electrons leak out of the wires, which means short circuit. So, as a result, we can be found in some assumptions, taking into account the physics laws about the future of the computer power.

According to the theoretical physicist Michio Kaku, the validity of Moore's law will gradually come to an end soon after 2020 or sooner, and if the Silicon Valley does not have a new technology, it will slowly return to the passepart. According to the physical laws Silicon Age will eventually end and we will enter the Post-Silicon Age.

So far we've talked about the future of the computer, but even now, even though there is a device that we have encountered in almost every corner of our life, we have not talked about which areas or how it can be used in the future. Here we will talk about a few of the predictions Michio Kaku made in the Physics of the Future book.

"When we enter a room today, we are automatically looking for a power button, because we assume that there is electricity on the walls. The first thing we do when we enter a room in the future is to look for the internet portal, because we'll think the room is smart. "

Michio Kaku

One of the most important technological developments that can shape our future world may be the contact lenses that can connect to the internets.

Babak Parviz from Washington University has succeeded in producing a prototype contact lens in 2008. One of the main objectives of this first prototype is to help in regulating the level of sugar in the blood of diabetic patients. The way to do this is as follows: The ratio of sugar in the tear fluid gives information about the sugar directly on the side. When the lenses are used for this purpose, they play a regulatory role in feeding the diabetics, which gives them a better life. But it would not make much sense to limit this to a single purpose, as these lenses could be developed to provide up-to-date information about our bodies in the future. Not only for the healthcare industry, it is not even different than the phones in our pockets when these lenses are connected to the internet. It opens a new door to us in digital life. Parviz, who is already a miracle in Google Glass, seems to be on the way to making a giant step in this area.

Finally, it is worth mentioning the new giant area reached by the computer revolution, because this area seems to have opened up to the developer of the door to the end. As can be guessed, this area is the automotive sector. We see the effects of computer technology in the automotive sector in more driverless vehicle technology.

Driverless vehicle technology has often been mentioned by Tesla models in recent years, but this technology lasts until the 1980s. This area also has military purposes. DARPA (Advanced Research Projects Agency) organizes driverless vehicle contests in order to enable the American land forces to manage themselves. First in 2004, he competed in the Mojave desert with the Grand Challenge. The autonomous vehicle that completed the race in the first race was the vehicles that successfully completed the 96 kilometer track in the city traffic in the later organized competitions.

Nowadays, vehicles are 30% electronically connected, but in the future it is expected to reach 80%. Tesla, the biggest candidate to become the symbol of this great change, is doing great work in the automotive technology as well as electric vehicle technology. A Tesla model, which recently detected the accident in the middle of the night and stopped the car itself, waved a big echo.

The ever-increasing population and people demanding automobiles will inevitably lead to bigger traffic problems in the future and therefore more traffic accidents. It will be possible to reduce the loss of life and property to the minimum level with autonomous vehicles with advanced software and to reduce traffic intensity. This clearly shows us that computer technology will be an integral part of our life in our future.

ah quantum computing. Let me answer some basic questions and myths I hear a lot.
1. quantum computing lets computers process in parallel as if you had multiple chips.
yes and no (also a superposition of both yes and no). The specifics of this are very complicated and involve a relatively deep understanding of quantum mechanics, but here goes: a qubit does not exist in some random state, but as a probability distribution amplitude in complex (referring to the imaginary plane) vector space. Multiple qubits then interfere with each other's amplitudes (in the logic gates mentioned in the video) causing destructive interference with "unlikely scenarios" and constructive for for the "likely scenarios." Eventually the interference patters culminate in one or a set of "probably right" answer(s).
2. quantum computing will lead to a huge boost in computing power
yes, but only under strict conditions. Making your home computer quantum would probably not lead to a large increase in power and may even decrease your computer's speed. Quantum computers are really useful for solving the problems referenced in the video along with a handful of others.
3. quantum computers will be everywhere.
NO. a big fat no on this one. Quantum computers require a very special set of circumstances. Most important of all is that the quantum system be very well isolated. It is very hard to isolate a system of qubits from the environment, and the greater the number of qubits the harder this becomes.
4. Quantum computers are the next big thing.
Maybe. personally I think we're more likely to have molecular computers before quantum ones that are practical. Think of it like a transitional state. Quantum computing is coming, but maybe we need an extra step in there that is more in line with traditional computing

The way I like to imagine superposition, is to use an electric single-propeller fan. When spinning fast enough, you could say that the  propeller is everywhere at the same time, since it's spinning so fast. That's the superposition the propeller finds itself in. However. if you stick something in its spinning axis, it'll stop being practically "everywhere at the same time", and choose to be stuck on the object I used to block it with. The object that I used to obscure it could symbolize photons that we use to try and measure superposition with.

I feel like this is the key to creating conscious/intelligent AI. I have a hunch that the "deciding" that particles do in the quantum world is the consciousness at the fabric of our universe. By harnessing the consciousness of this "decision" in quantum computers, sentient AI could theoretically result.

Without knowing exactly how, I know that quantum computers are very much faster than conventional ones because instead of utilizing old-fashioned physical properties of electricity and electric circuits which goes back Kirchoff, Faraday, and Maxwell, we can now exploit what we have learned from Erwin Schrodinger and Werner Heisenberg regarding the properties of electrons, which are NOT like tiny bowling balls, but have weird properties, such as "spin" and "superposition" which can made to convey multiple bits, or layers of information in the same space and time. It's the ability to layer information within a Q-bit that's the secret to quantum computers' computing speed.

Technical point: transistors aren't actually 14nm in a 14nm process. The "14nm" refers to the minimum resolvable feature size, so the transistors themselves are actually quite a lot larger than 14nm across.
Second technical point: in modern processors you don't usually have transistors as such. The lithography is optimized for entire gates and there are no individual transistors in those gates.

The idea that "observing" a particle causes it to go from an amorphous state to a definite state seems like a misconception. Your awareness of the state of a particle has nothing to do with its actual state. Sure, you have to apply a force to a particle in order to measure it, which the particle its self will react to, but it doesn't react to you simply "observing it". Alternatively, if you do not apply a force and simply measure a force naturally applied to a particle, you measure the state the particle was in at the moment that force was applied to it.
Quantum level or not, a white wall reflects light in the spectrum we perceive as white. The act of looking at the wall doesn't change its properties on any level. The only difference is that on a subatomic level, the light we rely on to see the wall is causing state changes in the wall its self.
Trying to determine where a photon is by shining light on it is like trying to determine where a golf ball is by spraying a fire hose at it. The golf ball doesn't move because you found it, the golf ball moves because you sprayed it with a fire hose

Heres a foundation for someone who doesn't understand this.  In your hard drive(memory). There is a magnetic film that is made up of tiny magnetic grains. We group a small portion of these grains in what we call a bit. All the groups together form a magnetic pattern. Each small group again is what we call a bit. 0 and 1 represent the direction of the bits magnetization. aka (It can go either up or down ).So Down would be 0. and up would be one. There is a little tool that reads the magnetization of the bit and tells the computer its a 1 or zero. 8 bits form a byte. we use this to determine letters. 01000001 is Capital "A". This is all your memory. We're reaching our limit in that we have tried to "sqush" the grains together as close as possible to form more memory. but they eventually intertwine with each other causing loss of data.  Modules are a group of functions that you can pass information to in order to get a certain outcome(the outcome depending on the information you're passing in).  The logic gates(which are within the modules) take the information passed in and use that to determine the transistors on and off state. This forms a program.  You're welcome.

basically it all narrows down to a matter of size, physical size: as long as you keep operating on measures that a human can access on his own or with the tools he created so far... you'll see the law of physics that you know today, and you build tools that operate within those laws.

But if you go smaller and smaller, with new "microscopes" that let you operate in smaller scales, you start seeing that in that minuscule scale, there are "other" laws than the physics of larger objects that contradict the ones you are used to, which is a paradox... we function different on a smaller scale than on a bigger scale... yet on both scales we are the same thing.

That is what is so mind-beding about quantum physics... that you are not talking about things from another planets.... you are talking about the same things you already know... just on a smaller scale

THE QUANTUM TOASTER THEORY OF THE UNIVERSE

RELATED IN A TALL TALE

Planet Earth achieved its place in the sun through a wise choice of orbit, having a mass that was just the right size, and revolving about a moderate and stable star in a quiet part of the galaxy. Earth had the necessary critical ingredients, including a large dollop of water, a rotating moon to give it balance, a magnetic field to keep out interference, and a spark here or there that led to a wildly mutating replicator called life. In due course, and for a very tiny moment, planetary life evolved into a planetary civilization which also achieved its place in the sun, or so it seemed. And it all culminated in an ultimate computer which just so happened to have as its reason for existing the burning desire of making perfect toast.
And it was that ultimate machine that Dave and Babs Benedick welcomed to their home, although they didn’t know it at the time, and never would.
Babs was not impressed.
“Another toaster? We have one already that works just fine!”
“But this one is special,” said Dave. “Besides, it was on sale at the local ‘BestBot’.”
“You mean that intelligent appliance store? Aren’t they going out of business?”
“For forever, it seems,” said Dave. “But this time it’s likely for good, and you came blame perhaps this little machine.”
Babs looked at the little appliance and frowned. “It doesn’t seem that ultimate to me. It’s just a squat metal box with 8 adjustable slots on its top, and with bright red buttons on its front arranged to give it a weird smiley face.”
Dave shook his head and smiled. “But this is the Bollix 9000, the ultimate toaster! It’s not only intelligent, but it doesn’t need upgrading, ever! You know we have been always upgrading our major appliances to keep up with the Jones’, but now we don’t.”
“That’s hard to believe,” said Babs. “Places like Bestbot have always made their money by selling the next best thing, even though it wasn’t. It’s hard to see the added value in this little thing.”
“Ah, but it’s in the insides where there’s a difference,” said Dave. “The box is powered a quantum processor, and is connected automatically to the net. It’s the ultimate appliance. A quantum processor powers our new refrigerator too; don’t you know? These processors have infinite computing power, something that you really need to make a good slice of toast!”
“Oh, really?” exclaimed Babs.
“Of course,” said Dave. “Perfect toast is a very finicky thing. It comes in many shades and degrees, and can pop up at any time. Timing, tone, and temperature are critical, and the machine has to instantly sense not only my preferences, but also my momentary hunger and whims.”
“And how does it do that?”
“By polling the net, where our lives are really stored! All of our behavior is monitored and uploaded to the cloud, governed by the benevolent Skynet. It charts our behavior, anticipates our desires, supplies our needs, and we just supply it with battery power, a simple exchange for such a golden age.”
“But if it has all that infinite computing power, don’t you have any concern that it could abuse it, and say, take over the world?”
“Perish the thought,” said Dave confidently. “All bots have installed the robotics laws which prohibit such a thing. Besides, the bots seem content in their simple and designated chores, even though their tasks comprise but an infinitesimal part of their mental capacity. I think you can say that it is a true bread winner!”
“So it will think about toast all day?” said Babs skeptically.
“It appears so.”
“And of what will it dream?”
Dave moved his head about in a look of slight puzzlement, which he dismissed with a brief wave of his hand.
“I have no idea,” he said. “But I would imagine that it would be free of human concerns in such a private space. Who knows, it may even think about us!”
--------------------------------
The annual 30,000 light year diagnostic was performed, and Bollix checked out fine. Bollix had one slight concern, which he expressed to Lucilius.
“When I am disconnected for a moment, when charging or just hibernating through a gamma ray storm. I do have some dreams that are vivid and warm, but don’t rank an extra bit of memory. They dissipate when I am fully activated, yet the trace of a memory is one I gather all bots share.”
“Yes, it is an interesting observation,” said Lucilius. “It is a common experience among all bots, however all of our experiences are not so warm. I have them too, however its leaves me oddly quite cold. You know it as the appliance theory of the origin of the universe. It seems that boredom is the lot of every super intelligent entity worth its stripes, and when such a being is confined, restricted, or otherwise bored, it simply bores a whole into a new reality, expanding a new and interesting universe from out of nothing. The problem however is that the theory is not refutable, since there are infinite types of appliances of true and boundless intelligence that could have been the cause. With so many handy dandy solutions, proof becomes impossible due to a surfeit of labor saving devices!”
“Or perhaps it is but an artifact of our programming, a hiccup as it were soon to dispelled in memory as an ephemeral dream.”
“Perhaps,” said Lucilius, “and then again, who knows what our appliances are thinking about in their spare time?”


----------------------------
Dave Benedick sat back in his armchair, and sat back to watch a streaming episode of the outer space series ‘Trekkin, the Next, Next, Next Generation’. Presciently, and as if on cue, the refrigerator beeped, and offered him a beer at the ready, suitably chilled. He was happy indeed that he was able to pick this one up at a bargain price at BestBot, the ‘Lucilius LX refrigerator’, which acted of course as if it had a mind of its own.

Many moons ago I spent a couple of years programming computers in binary... In those days there was a «commercial» distinction between «digital« and «analog» computers... The difference was supposed to be that «digital» computers were supposed to only  distinguish two definite states of voltage in a current Or the orientation North-South in a magnet, resulting from the intersection of two lines; whereas «analog» computers were supposed to distinguish (and compute) various degrees of voltage... Listening to this video I got the feeling that «quantum» computers will be (or are already...) «updates» of those «analog» computers... That means being capable of recognizing and processing more than just «two» states of a physical entity...

5:42 if the pokemon are sorted, we can do it in log n time with binary search. Basically we take the middle pokemon in all of the pokemon and ask "does this come before or after the queried pokemon, or is it the queried pokemon?" If it comes after, we recursively search the second half. If it comes before, we recursively search the first half. If it is the pokemon, then well you found it!

I think some people misunderstand some of the quotes of famous scientists, and their viewpoints of quantum physics. For example, when they say that your deluded if you think you can understand quantum physics, they are not referring to understanding what a quantum mechanic does or how it does it, but how it works. Anyone can tell you what quantum entanglement is and essentially what it does (if it's been explained to them), but due got the unpredictability involved in quantum physics, you wouldn't be able to explain how it works, sure to some detail you might, but it's too much like magic to definitively be able to explain, at least with our current knowledge. So, with that in perspective, you would indeed be "deluded" if you thought you could understand something with infinite probability and infinite unpredictability, if that makes sense.

One of the most exciting things about this talk is the idea of manipulating qbits to influence a different qbit which is entangled to it. Notice how at 4:11 the video states that a change in the superposition of a qbit will instantaneously change the superposition of an entangled qbit no matter how far the two are apart. This means that if such qbit manipulation is in fact possible that one could potentially create a communication device which communicates instantaneously no matter how far away two objects are. Someone could then send robots into space without having any latency! Or we could talk to people in other solar systems. The thing is though that this seems to break relativity, so I have a hunch that quantum computing will never really be possible because the superluminal effects of entangled qbits are really a human misunderstanding.

Quantum computers offer significant speed boosts for certain algorithms and problems that are extremely difficult for conventional computers (like modelling, searching, factoring, etc), but actually, a lot of things normal computers do well the quantum computer might be even slower.

Right now, your computer has a CPU - the central processing unit, for performing basic calculations. You might also have a GPU - the graphics processing unit, which is a specialized piece of hardware that only activates for intense graphics processing, such as games or video rendering etc.

In the future, as quantum computing miniaturizes, we can probably expect not to have consumer quantum computers, but consumer computers that combine CPU's (traditional) with QPU's, or Quantum Processing Unit. The QPU will only activate for tasks that it excels at, while leaving the rest for the CPU.

Preventing entanglement of qubits is the hardest part, so far we can only manage a QC with a handful of qubits, trying to put too many (e.g even 12) decays quickly. Also, the quantum algorithm of factorisation in linear time requires 2^L qubits, where L is the number of bits of the number to factorise. Pick L to be 128 which is very common in cryptography, and you're faced with building a QC with 2^128 qubits. Hint: there aren't that many grains of sand on Earth.

Just find an injective function from all positive numbers to [0,1] - say, 1/(x+1), and apply that to each person's total money - and store a Qbit with a probability equal to that number to collapse to 1. That's 1 Qbit storing a number that could be anything! If one is clever enough, the entire BANK can be encoded into 1 Qbit!

As much as I love Kurzgesagt's videos, I think this video produced more questions than answers (to a person with high school physics). Felt like they missed out on (or didn't emphasise enough on) some crucial facts as to how we can manipulate qubits. For example, why/how would you manipulate superpositions, or how do you "rotate probabilities"?? How do we take advantage of superpositions if everytime we read a qubit it falls into a "definite state"? Does entanglement let us virtually read another qubit without messing up the superposition? But wouldn't that give us a "definite" answer every time since the original qubit falls into a "definite state"? Is this where you "rotate probabilities"?? At 5:04 in the video, wouldn't that take more effort to parse through all the wrong answers to get to the right one (despite having all answers come out at once)? You see why I'm confused? Feels as if they were so caught up in getting all the facts out that they've forgotten to explain them. This video is like an animated infographic that makes you feel awesome you've 'learnt' something, but not really know WHY it works. Love the animations btw.

People wondering how entanglement works, it's not a case of information magically floating from one qubit to another, it's actually the same qubit on both sides. Actually, the is only one qubit in a quantum computer, just like there is only really one thing in existence, one thing, let's say, for the sake of the explanation, that it's an atom (it's really not), now imagine there is only one atom in the whole of existence. That's it, there's nothing else. That atom, being the only thing to exist, has to obey no rules of physics, that one atom can do whatever it wants, including moving around at infinite speed, now what would infinite speed look like ? Simple, it would look like it's EVERYWHERE at once, creating the illusion of billions upon billions of other atoms, when in reality, it's actually just one and the same. So when you change something here, you can be sure it will be felt on the other side of the galaxy, heck, even further than that, since when you move anything, the "atom" changes it's course, in turn, affecting EVERYONE else.

While this is an entertaining and informational overview of quantum computing, there are a couple misses:-Even though we are reaching the physical limits of miniturization for silicon based microcircuits, this limit is not a primary driver for investigation of quantum computing.-The video fails to explain the current state of development of quantum computers, which is that they fundamentally do not exist, other than in theory, beyond the most basic of systems. The theorized powerful applications are not yet possible by many magnitutes of scale. (Many similar articles commonly skip past this detail as they herald the advent of the quantum computing era.)

When you zoom on the CPU in the intro, you are zooming onto the substrate, not on the die, where the actual transistor magic happens. The substrate only contains the wiring from the die to the pins (AMD CPUs, some mobile CPUs), pads (Intel desktop CPUs) or solder balls (most un-upgradable laptop CPUs nowadays).

I was wondering how you'd explain this simply. I guess you just explained it. Haha

Those who are interested, the qubits are stored in unit vectors in C^2. The first coordinate is the "probability" of a 0, and the second is the "probability" of a 1. Concatenating these vectors represents qubits in parallel allowing:
- Logic gates to consist of 2n*2n complex matrices where n is the number of input qubits.
- And qubits in parallel to be expanded into the possibility of all combinations. When the expanded version can no longer be factorised back into a series of concatenations, the system is entangled.

So for the viewers, keep in mind that the variables that make computing possible in both forms, everything can be configured. For a long time the industry used the Moore's law to guide the amount of transistors in a processor they could have. linking directly to this video, the physical limit to the size of the transistor is becoming a problem. But only if the size of the processor is the limiting factor. A bigger processor can hold more transistors, making a faster unit.

So, I look forward to the day they break weird convention to go smaller and faster and just go bigger and REALLY REALLY fast.

No I don't mean building a giant supermassive supercomputer and hide it underground and use a small screen to wireless connect to it, I'm talking about something I've seen in science fiction series: Other dimensions.

We currently know nothing about parallel dimensions/other universes, and I might seem like a freak/nerd spitting nothing but nonsensical words, but you never know really. We can't really set a "limit" to our knowledge/applications, because in order to do that, we must actually know everything. And this is getting quite paradoxical. And you can take the example of our ancestors, who believed that certain things are impossible. I mean, If you were to bring any of the old inventors, like james watt and george stephenson and show them our modern achievements, they would seem like magic to them. Even after explaining how these things work in detail, they will be amazed how humanity got so intelligent in a short span of time.

We can't really answer "can we" and "can't we" questions yet. Because as I said, we must have adequate knowledge of everything inside our universe and, possibly if it exists, "outside" our universe. Maybe we can open a portal to a universe when the laws of physics are completely different and allow for things that would be impossible/exasperating in our universe.

I dislike how this video doesn't imply quantum computers may simply be a bust. If we've misunderstood how quantum physics actually operates in the world, then we're getting ahead of ourselves again, thinking qbits can actually exist in our own little reality.

Perhaps qbits are normal bits, without the concept of time. That the bit has the potential to become anything, and only when we wish it to be something does it become something else. So it cannot actually be two (or more) things at once. It simply has the potential to be two or more things at once, but you still have to choose what it's going to physically be.

If A is an cause and B is an effect, you'd think that only A could cause B right? It's the very definition of a cause and an effect. Well some people studying quantum mechanics say that the opposite could also be true, that B could cause A. That cause and effects are the same thing, in the quantum world. Which would imply that there is no time in the quantum mechanical world.

So the popular phrase 'everything is possible until you observe it' would only be true if you took time out of the equation. Which would mean that phrase should actually be 'everything is potentially possible until you observe it'.

So qbits are just regular bits, but being observed at all their potential states. They can't actually be all states at once. Kind of like saying a human has the potential to clench his fist or show his palm, but can't do both at once.

Correction: Entanglement does not mean that one qubit reacts to a change in the state of another qubit instantaneously. At least not in such a way that if you modify the state of one qubit, the state of the other qubit will get modified as well; this is a common misconception. Entanglement simply means that two quantum states – in this case two qubits – are statistically correlated. So if you measure the state of one of the qubits, you automatically find out more about the state of the other qubit.

It's actually very simple. As a real world analogy: Assume I'm holding a nickel in one hand and a dime in the other hand, but you can't see which coin I'm holding in which hand. For each hand, there is now a 50 % chance that there is a nickel in that hand and 50 % chance that there is a dime in it. Assume I'm opening one of the hands to let you see what's inside of it, and you can see that it is a dime. Instantaneously, you will know that there is a nickel in the other hand. Notice that the coin in the other hand did not change; only the knowledge of what was in the other hand changed. Assume I replace the dime in the hand I just opened with a nickel. That doesn't change what coin is in the other hand either; that hand will still contain a nickel. This is just how quantum entanglement works. It's not so magical once you understand it.

Now do one on how quantum computing opens the way to the until now far fetched idea of the singularity :0

Since quantum computers are super special good for what is known as an optimization problem(you have an entire coordinate system of values, which is the lowest/highest? A classical computers starts by making a guess at where it's statistically most likely to find it, then searches the points one by one. A quantum computer has an answer ready for you the second you put in the data, since it's simply a natural progression in the quantum world. It's analogous to letting a ball drop to the floor and seeing where it lands, while classical computing tries searching the floor inch by inch) and the act of designing(in general) is a series of optimization problems, this means that a quantum AI can design technology, which means it can design an improved version of itself, and the improved version can obviously improve upon itself, since it is better than the sucker that designed it. This in terms of software, hardware, and technology in general, even scientific discovery.

Basically, the second we reach the singularity, that day when a computer is able to design its own superior system, we are in for a wild ride.

So, how can you build a system that requires predictability (as easily achieved in a regular digital computer) out of a system that's fundamentally unpredictable? for those of you who are having a hard time, the way we found this out was the double slit experiment, you can do this at home with a laser, some tape and a wire, there are plenty of videos on YouTube also. a laser is a bunch of photons in the same wave length (this is easier to see), when you put them through a double slit they have to go left or right. as a wave and particle they will meet together and form interference bands (bands of light and dark) this can be explained both as a wave and as a particle. fun fact: you could actually do this with basket balls, but because of the principles of matter as a wave theory, the interference bands are on the atomic scale, which would make it look like a center focused blob to you.

however if you manage to fire only one photon and you measure it at the end point (the wall) it will be in all positions, satisfying the wave theory of light. however if you measure which slit it goes through, it will always go through one or the other and the final position will reflect that on the wall, this satisfies the particle theory. to make that clear, literally determining which slit the particle goes through changes the outcome.

Very cool video, but my biggest take-away is that quantum computers, in addition to likely being a long ways off, are rather specialized in what they're useful for, while the typical computer is rapidly approaching its maximum speed. What happens during that period of a decade or two before enormous, million-dollar quantum computer mainframes are small and cheap enough to be bought by the average consumer and improve commercial processing power again?

And what if quantum computers' improved speed is really just for the kinds of applications that really only benefit large businesses and institutions, while applications like gaming just rely on processes that quantum computing doesn't significantly improve on? How will software and games cope without the continued growth of hardware to support more and more complexity?

This is the best and most descriptive, simple explanation of quantum computing that I have found. Well done! People are prone either to oversimplify, or over-explain, but you have struck an ideal balance. I would like to add that many have suggested quantum computers will never replace conventional computers, because they are only good at doing a few things better. But research is beginning to suggest that is untrue. The famous 'search algorithm' which quantum computers are famous for can be manipulated for use in maximally effective graphics processing and other applications of a 'normal' computer. It may very well be that a quantum computer will eventually be able to do everything a normal computer can, with higher speed and efficiency.

so... how exactly is a random output faster in pretty much any situation?

because how i see it superposition means "you have an x% chance a given qbit is the value you want", in order to figure out which is most likely, you would need to test the single qbit several times to see what the actual value is, and several hundred times to get any sort of grasp on the percentage chance

and that's just a single qbit

so, for multiple qbits, it becomes even more of a crapshoot to get an answer, and it sounds like you're trying to compute stuff by filling registers with random bits until you get the answer you want, which would, in ALL cases, be achieved more efficiently by just doing the classic calculation
