Beacuse this was the outmost shittiest way of explaining quantum computers I give you a shorter version.

They make a filter with lots of holes that are the quantum bits. They throw everything about you trough it, and it instantly filters out a lot of juicy fact about you and using statistic likellyness they identify what is that you most likelly are.
On normal computers they do the same, but it takes them ages to run all your crap trough this filter 1000 times to have a clear statistically relevant picture of you. Quantum computers does this INSTANTLY.

To use such a computing technique you have to build up a calculation method wich is full of variables only. Mainly algebra if you heard of it.
Once you got your superlong and specific chain of mathmatical(ish) jiberrish you put a quantum computer section in it and connect them togather with the funny shape gates you saw in the video (OR, XOR, AND, etc google it) then once everything is set up, you just flip the switch of the few transistors at the begining wich are regular inputs and then the quantum computer basicly generates all possible solution according to your input in an instant, since this is probably a crapton of information in an instant you have to narrow it down what you actually interested in (if the calculation was small and simple to begin with you dont need much narrowing or at all), and by narrowing down it is mostly statistical likellyness.

This is mostly true except the part about Public and private key.
Public key can not be reversed to private key. The only possible way is by bruteforcing. That however would take over billions of years to callculate every single possibillity on a standard SHA 2 encrytpion(on a super computer) Just think of hash as a open box where you store the key to decrypt the file. But the boxes are total 2^256(amount of them) (the total atoms in entire universe is believed to be somewhere around 2^266) The private key you get is the address to the box that stores the right date to decrypt the data.

Now this is the sort of content that everyone has been wanting and asking for over the last few months. Although I know it is tempting and interesting to try to cover much more complex and controversial topics, but this style of content presentation is simply the best for explaining really complex science things in really simple ways. Really good video, but not quite accurate.
We need quantum physics to build smaller transistors, BUT we don't use these transistors for quantum computers. We try to suppress quantum effects when designing transistors and try to enhance them in a quantum computer. I think that wasn't clear in the video.

Also the most important quantum effect that we use in quantum computing is interference. It is what does the calculation. Entanglement is mainly needed so we can use the entire 2^n-sized basis, but for that we could also use a single system with 2^n levels without entanglement.

Nonetheless the best video on quantum computing I've seen on youtube. The animations are on point!

Quantum computing would not "ruin" IT security. In fact, some parts of IT security would actually profit from quantum computers.

It is true that efficient quantum computers would make many of the currently used crypto algorithms obsolete. But this has nothing to do with them being "public key" systems, but rather the math behind the algorithms which are currently used. In fact, we also know several public key crypto systems resistant to quantum computers and there is a lot of research in the era of "post-quantom cryptography" going on right know. Alright KurzGesagt, here is what I really don't get about quantum-entanglement / -computing (maximum nerd-mode engaged; you have been warned):
When you talk about a superposition, where a piece of information is in several states at once, that collapses into a single state once you measure it, isn't that just fancy physics-talk for "I don't know what state this thing is in; but if I measure it, I'll find out".

In my brain's logic, everything in the universe has exactly one state at any time, whether we measure it or not; the notion of superposition just doesn't make any sense to me, because "collapsing a superposition" is the same to me as figuring out the current state that the piece of matter would have had, regardless of whether or not I measured it at that time.

Think of it this way: Assume you have a time-machine, and you take a measurement of a q-bit and detect its spin/value. Then you travel back in time and detect its spin again (at the exact same moment, under the exact same circumstances). Does you measurement produce the same result?

If yes, then the q-bit was in that state no matter what, and you detected its current state; the talk about superposition boils down to "what state does it have?".

Kurz, the first half of this video is not correct. You are describing transistors as the building material of processors (which is correct), but then staying that technological advancement = building material advancement, which is not correct.

For a simple way to understand my argument, picture how humans have built their homes over the years; we've gone from stones to bricks and timbers to all sorts of advanced materials, but they have not been the limit of how "good" our homes are. The arrangement is. Two homes may be identical size with identical building material, but one home may have 3 bedrooms 1 bathroom and the other may have 2 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms (as a simple example.) The homes, while having identical material and physical square footage, are vastly different. Neither is objectively better, simply better at different things. One may be able to comfortably house a larger family, while that same house may be too big for a small family, but be very bad if you need two bathrooms (perhaps one family member has health complications and needs his own bathroom for his medical equipment).

Processor design is a VERY large industry, and trivializing this industry by only being as advanced as one of its departments incorrect.

Even if the building material reaches a prime, the processor architectures will vary wildly, and CPU x may be better at calculating certain calculations such as SIMD than CPU y which handles serial processing incredibly quickly.

Anyways, fine video nonetheless.
